Pre-Game Insights: Pat Cummins believes the middle overs are the most crucial period in the 50-over format, and Australia are falling behind their World Cup rivals in this area.

Quinton de Kock thinks most teams not from the subcontinent would have struggled against India's quality spin attack in the conditions they faced, but the Proteas are contemplating bringing Tabraiz Shamsi into their lineup to face Australia.

Steve Smith said the focus of Australia's batting group heading into the tournament has been extending partnerships and playing according to each surface given the differing conditions across the World Cup venues in India.

David Warner, Steve Smith, Marnus Labuschagne, and Glenn Maxwell have been praised for their ability to play spin well, which could be an advantage for Australia against South Africa's bowling attack.
Miscellaneous Highlights: South Africa racked up a tournament record 5-428 in their first match in Delhi, while Sri Lanka failed to defend 9-344 in their second match in Hyderabad.
India have taken the most middle overs wickets in 2023, with 114 wickets at a strike rate of 28.09.
Tabraiz Shamsi may be brought into South Africa's lineup to face Australia, as the surface at Lucknow's Ekana Stadium is tipped to be similar to the conditions they faced in Chennai.

Australia have lost the most wickets per innings between overs 11-40 in one-day internationals this year, with a bowling strike rate of 35.41 during the same period, which is the second-highest behind only the Netherlands in 2023.
Others: Pat Cummins mentioned that taking regular wickets and limiting the damage during their own batting innings is a key component of global success in the 50-over format.
The middle overs (overs 11-40) have been a period where World Cups have been won and lost over the past three tournaments.
Australia's batting collapses have been a regular occurrence in the lead-up to the tournament, and it was again a problem in their first-up loss to hosts India in Chennai.
